title: Literature Review: Asteroid Lightcurve Inversion Methods

convex_inversion_KTM.mathematical_formulation: Gradient-based minimization of chi-squared between observed and synthetic lightcurves. Shape parameterized as convex hull via Gaussian surface density (Minkowski problem). Spherical harmonics or direct facet area representation. Levenberg-Marquardt optimization over spin axis (lambda, beta), sidereal period P, and shape parameters.
strengths: Mathematically well-posed: convexity constraint guarantees uniqueness
Robust convergence with gradient-based methods
Works with as few as ~10-20 lightcurves spanning 3+ apparitions
Produces physically reasonable convex hulls even for non-convex bodies
Foundation of DAMIT database (5700+ models as of 2021)
limitations: Cannot resolve concavities, craters, or bifurcated shapes
Bilinear non-convex optimization problem prone to local minima
Requires good phase angle coverage for reliable pole determination
Period search is computationally expensive (brute-force grid)
convex_inversion_KTM.open_problems: Global optimality not guaranteed; deep learning approaches being explored as alternatives

SAGE_genetic_evolution.mathematical_formulation: Genetic algorithm with population of non-convex shapes encoded as vertex displacements. Fitness = chi-squared of lightcurve fit + regularization. Mutation operators: vertex perturbation, facet modification. Crossover between parent shapes. Selection via tournament. Converges over 100+ generations with population >= 50.
strengths: Produces non-convex shapes capturing craters, lobes, bifurcations
No convexity assumption - models closer to reality
Global search avoids local minima inherent in gradient methods
Successfully tested on Eros, Metis ground-truth data
Extensible to include stellar occultations and AO data
limitations: Computationally expensive (orders of magnitude slower than convex inversion)
Requires good initial period and approximate pole from convex inversion
Regularization needed to prevent overfitting with too many vertices
Uniform albedo assumption
SAGE_genetic_evolution.open_problems: Scalability to large surveys; combining with sparse data

sparse_data_inversion.mathematical_formulation: Extension of convex inversion to handle sparse photometric data (<100 points/apparition) from surveys (Gaia, Pan-STARRS, LSST). Key additions: (1) absolute magnitude calibration using H-G model to convert survey magnitudes to reduced magnitudes, (2) joint period+pole+shape fitting from sparse data alone, (3) Cellino approach uses triaxial ellipsoid + genetic algorithm for fast sparse inversion.
strengths: Enables shape modeling from survey data (Gaia DR3: 22,815 asteroids with 25+ measurements)
Can be combined with dense data for improved accuracy
Gaia provides unprecedented photometric precision
Expected to yield 10,000+ new models from upcoming surveys
limitations: Period ambiguities more severe with sparse sampling
Shape resolution limited compared to dense data
Requires precise absolute calibration of survey photometry
Phase angle coverage often limited within single survey
sparse_data_inversion.open_problems: Combining Gaia DR3 + LSST + ground-based data optimally

ADAM_multi_modal.mathematical_formulation: Unified framework for combining lightcurves, AO images, radar delay-Doppler, interferometry, occultation timings via 2D Fourier transform projections. Non-convex and non-starlike parametric shapes. Joint optimization of all data types with configurable weighting.
strengths: Most complete multi-modal approach available
Handles any combination of data types uniformly
Non-convex shapes without convexity constraint
Available as open-source (MATLAB + C)
limitations: Requires multiple data types for best results
Complex setup and configuration
Computationally intensive for large vertex counts
Needs initial shape estimate (typically from convex inversion)
ADAM_multi_modal.open_problems: Automation for large-scale surveys; incorporating thermal infrared data

KOALA.mathematical_formulation: Knitted Occultation, Adaptive-optics, and Lightcurve Analysis. Combines lightcurve inversion with AO images and stellar occultation silhouettes.
strengths: Good for asteroids with occultation data
Provides absolute size scaling
limitations: Requires occultation and/or AO data not available for most asteroids
Less flexible than ADAM

MPO_LCInvert.description: Commercial implementation of Kaasalainen-Durech convex inversion with user-friendly GUI. Based on convexinv code.
strengths: User-friendly wizard interface
Well-tested on many asteroids
limitations: Commercial (not open source)
Convex shapes only
No sparse data handling

Lommel_Seeliger.description: Simplest physically-motivated scattering law: brightness proportional to mu_0/(mu_0+mu) where mu_0=cos(incidence), mu=cos(emission). Single-scattering approximation.

Hapke.description: Full bidirectional reflectance model including single-scattering albedo, particle phase function, opposition effect (SHOE), macroscopic roughness. Most physically complete but more parameters to fit.

H_G_model.description: IAU standard two-parameter phase function for absolute magnitude calibration. H=absolute magnitude, G=slope parameter. Used for sparse data reduction.

open_source_tools_identified.capabilities: LC simulation and MCMC shape recovery

open_source_tools_identified.capabilities: Synthetic lightcurve generation from shape models

summary: The field of asteroid lightcurve inversion is mature for convex shapes (Kaasalainen-Torppa method, 5700+ models in DAMIT) but significant opportunities remain in: (1) non-convex shape recovery via genetic algorithms (SAGE), (2) sparse data exploitation from Gaia/LSST surveys, (3) multi-modal data fusion (ADAM). Our pipeline synthesizes all three approaches with a focus on sparse data handling and non-convex refinement to model previously uncharacterized asteroids.
